facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 276 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 276 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 15, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 224 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated October 15, 1954 of Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 224 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 15, 1954, of the Allahabad High Court in Execution First Appeal No. 224 of 1951. P. Sinha and Tiryugi Narain for the appellants.

facts.text: Decree made by Civil Judge, Kanpur on September 2, 1938 in a suit for partition.

anchor.surface_text: The decree sought to be executed was made by the Civil Judge, Kanpur, on September 2, 1938, in a suit for partition brought by two brothers Jumna Prasad and Devi Prasad and two minor sons of Jumna Prasad, against Gajju Lal,

facts.text: Partition suit brought by Jumna Prasad, Devi Prasad and two minor sons of Jumna Prasad against Gajju Lal, Jawala Prasad, four minor sons of Jawala Prasad (Sharda Prasad, Dharam Pal, Ram Pal, Krishna Pal), and Smt. Sundari.

anchor.surface_text: in a suit for partition brought by two brothers Jumna Prasad and Devi Prasad and two minor sons of Jumna Prasad, against Gajju Lal, his son Jawala Prasad, the four minor sons of Jawala Prasad-Sharda Prasad, Dharam Pal, Ram Pal and Krishna Pal, and one Smt. Sundari.

facts.text: House formerly bearing No. 36/22 and 36/58, Etawa Bazar, Kanpur awarded to defendants in the partition decree.

anchor.surface_text: By the decree one of the properties, a house formerly bearing No. 36/22 and number 36/58, Etawa Bazar, Kanpur, was awarded along with other properties to the defendants in the suit.

facts.text: Execution application made by Sharda Prasad, Dharam Pal, Ram Pal and Krishna Pal on November 23, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The present application for execution was made by the four brothers, Sharda Prasad, Dharam Pal, Ram Pal and Krishna Pal on Novem- ber 23, 1949.

facts.text: Prayer in execution application for delivery of possession of Etawa Bazar house, dispossess Jumna Prasad and Devi Prasad, along with Gajju Lal, Jawala Prasad and Smt. Sundari.

anchor.surface_text: The prayer was that these applicants may be delivered possession over this Etawa Bazar house along with Gajju Lal, Jawala Prasad and Smt. Sundari on dispossession of Jumna Prasad and Devi Prasad.

facts.text: Execution applicants were minors up till then, one still minor.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated in the application that all these applicants had up till number been minors and one of them is still a minor and so numberquestion in respect of time arises.

facts.text: This was the first application for execution of the partition decree.

anchor.surface_text: This it is important to numbere, was the first application for execution of the partition decree. A number of objections were raised but the principal objection

facts.text: Principal objection: execution application barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: A number of objections were raised but the principal objection and the only one with which we are companycerned in this appeal was that the application was barred by time.

facts.text: Question: Jawala Prasad could give discharge under decree without concurrence of minor sons, so time ran under s.7 Limitation Act from decree date.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this question depended on the answer to the question raised on behalf of the opposite parties that Jawala Prasad one of the persons entitled jointly with these applicants to make an application for the execution of the decree companyld have given a discharge of the liability under the decree without the companycurrence of his minor sons and so time ran under s. 7 of the Limitation Act against them also from the date of the decree.

facts.text: Trial Court held Jawala Prasad could not give valid discharge, application within time.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court did number feel satisfied that Jawala Prasad companyld give a valid discharge and held accordingly that the application was within time.

facts.text: High Court held Jawala Prasad as Karta could act for family, give discharge by taking possession, application barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: on appeal the High Court held that Jawala Prasad as the Karta of the Hindu joint family companyld act on behalf of the entire joint family in taking possession of the house allotted to the defendants and delivery of such possession companyld discharge the liability qua the entire joint family and held accordingly that the application was barred by limitation.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) of Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court however granted a certificate under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution and on that certificate this appeal has been filed by the applicants for execution.

facts.text: Appellants contended s.7 Limitation Act does not apply to partition decree.

anchor.surface_text: Two companytentions were raised on behalf of the appellants in support of the plea that the High Court erred in holding that the application for execution was barred by limitation. First, it is urged that s. 7 of the Limitation Act does number apply at all to a partition decree.

facts.text: Appellants contended Jawala Prasad could not give valid discharge due to O.32 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The second companytention is that in any case Jawala Prasad companyld number give a valid discharge of the liability under the decree in view of the provisions of O. 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on February 20, 1961 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: P. Sinha and Tiryugi Narain for the appellants. C. Mathur, for respondent No. 1. 1961. February 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-This appeal raises a question of limitation in execution proceedings.

facts.text: Jawala Prasad is son of Gajju Lal and father of the four minor sons.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.7 applies to partition decrees, not limited to monetary claims.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion numbersubstance in this argument. The mere fact that the two illustrations to s. 7 are in respect of debts is numberground for thinking that the provisions of s. 7 are limited to suits or decrees on monetary claims only.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Jawala Prasad as Karta could give discharge by accepting possession on behalf of minors, without O.32 r.6 or r.7 applying.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that Jawala Prasad, the managing member of the family companyld have given a discharge of the liability under the partition decree by accepting delivery of possession on behalf of his minor sons without their companysent and so time ran against them also under s. 7 of the Limitation Act from the date of the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-This appeal raises a question of limitation in execution proceedings. The decree sought to be executed was made by the Civil Judge, Kanpur, on September 2, 1938, in a suit for partition

arguments.claim: The execution application is barred by time because Jawala Prasad could have given a discharge of the liability under the decree without the concurrence of his minor sons and so time ran under s. 7 of the Limitation Act against them also from the date of the decree.

anchor.surface_text: A number of objections were raised but the principal objection and the only one with which we are companycerned in this appeal was that the application was barred by time. The decision of this question depended on the answer to the question raised on behalf of the opposite parties that Jawala Prasad one of the persons entitled jointly with these applicants to make an application for the execution of the decree could have given a discharge of the liability under the decree without the companycurrence of his minor sons and so time ran under s. 7 of the Limitation Act against them also from the date of the decree.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court right; Karta power under Hindu law allows discharge via possession acceptance without O.32 application.

arguments.claim: s. 7 of the Limitation Act does not apply at all to a partition decree because the word discharge is appropriate only in respect of a monetary claim and is wholly inappropriate in respect of any decree for possession.

anchor.surface_text: Two companytentions were raised on behalf of the appellants in support of the plea that the High Court erred in holding that the application for execution was barred by limitation. First, it is urged that s. 7 of the Limitation Act does number apply at all to a partition decree. The second companytention is that in any case Jawala Prasad companyld number give a valid discharge of the liability under the decree in view of the provisions of O. 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure. On the first companytention the argument is that the word discharge is appropriate only in respect of a monetary claim and is wholly inappropriate in respect of any decree for possession whether on partition or otherwise.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e in respect of any decree for possession whether on partition or otherwise. There is, in our opinion numbersubstance in this argument. The mere fact

arguments.court_reasoning: No substance; discharge means free from liability, not limited to money; illustrations not exhaustive; s.8 exempts pre-emption implying broader; CPC judgment-debtor definition covers non-monetary.

arguments.claim: Jawala Prasad could not give a valid discharge of the liability under the decree in view of the provisions of O. 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion numbersubstance in this argument. The mere fact that the two illustrations to s. 7 are in respect of debts is numberground for thinking that the provisions of s. 7 are limited to suits or decrees on monetary claims only. Nor can we see any reason to think that the word discharge can refer only to debts. Discharge means, to free from liability.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e word discharge in s. 7 is number limited to discharge of monetary claims only but also to discharge or satisfaction of all other liabilities as well

arguments.court_reasoning: O.32 rr.6,7 apply to money/movables/receipts/agreements, not possession acceptance in partition; Karta under Hindu law can bind family; precedents like Ganesha Row distinguished as they concern compromises/money.

arguments.claim: s.7 Limitation Act applies to partition decrees as discharge not limited to monetary claims.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion numbersubstance in this argument. The mere fact that the two illustrations to s. 7 are in respect of debts is numberground for thinking that the provisions of s. 7 are limited to suits or decrees on monetary claims only. Nor can we see any reason to think that the word discharge can refer only to debts. Discharge means, to free from liability.

arguments.claim: Provisions of O.32 CPC do not debar Karta from giving discharge by accepting possession in partition decree; time ran under s.7 from decree date.

anchor.surface_text: Equally untenable is the second argument that the provisions of 0. 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure debar the manager of a Hindu joint family from giving discharge in respect of a liability to deliver properties. Under the Hindu Law the Karta of a Hindu joint family represents all the members of the family and has the power and duty to take action which binds the family in companynection with all matters of management of the family property.

holdings.text: s. 7 of the Limitation Act applies at all to a partition decree

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion nosubstance in this argument. The mere fact that the two illustrations to s. 7 are in respect of debts is numberground for thinking that the provisions of s. 7 are limited to suits or decrees on monetary claims only. Nor can we see any reason to think that the word discharge can refer only to debts. Discharge means, to free from liability. The liability may be in respect of monetary claims, like the debts it may be in respect of possession of property it may be in respect of taking some order as regards property it may be in respect of many other matters.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Word 'discharge' means to free from any liability, not just monetary; illustrations not limitative; s.8 exempts pre-emption suits indicating broader scope; CPC defines judgment-debtor for any executable decree.

holdings.text: provisions of O. 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure do not debar the manager of a Hindu joint family from giving discharge in respect of a liability to deliver properties

anchor.surface_text: Equally untenable is the second argument that the provisions of 0. 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure debar the manager of a Hindu joint family from giving discharge in respect of a liability to deliver properties. Under the Hindu Law the Karta of a Hindu joint family represents all the members of the family and has the power and duty to take action which binds the family in connection with all matters of management of the family property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Karta under Hindu law can bind family in property management including receiving possession; O.32 rr.6&7 apply only to money/movables/receipts/agreements/compromises, not possession acceptance in partition; precedents distinguished as involving compromises or money.

holdings.text: Jawala Prasad, the managing member of the family could have given a discharge of the liability under the partition decree by accepting delivery of possession on behalf of his minor sons without their consent and so time ran against them also under s. 7 of the Limitation Act from the date of the decree

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that Jawala Prasad, the managing member of the family could have given a discharge of the liability under the partition decree by accepting delivery of possession on behalf of his minor sons without their consent and so time ran against them also under s. 7 of the Limitation Act from the date of the decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: As Karta, Jawala Prasad could accept possession for joint family including minors without court permission under O.32; this constitutes discharge under s.7.

holdings.text: The High Court was therefore right in its conclusion that the application for execution was barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in its conclusion that the application for execution was barred by limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of s.7 via Karta's power to discharge leads to time running from 1938 decree date; 1949 application barred.

precedents.citation: Ganesha Row v. Tuljaram Row 1 1913 L.R. 40 I.A. 132,138

anchor.surface_text: In Ganesha Row v. Tuljaram Row 1 the Judicial Committee pointed out that- No doubt a father or managing member of a joint Hindu family may, under certain circum- stances and subject to certain companyditions, enter into agreements which may be binding on the minor members of the family. But where a minor is party to a suit and a next friend or guardian has been appointed to look after the rights and interests of the infant in and companycerning the suit, the acts of such next friend or guardian are subject to the companytrol of the Court.

precedents.cited_proposition: acts of such next friend or guardian are subject to the control of the Court; the managing member who had been appointed a guardian in the suit had no authority to enter into any compromise or agreement purporting to bind the minor
precedents.cited_holding: managing member who had been appointed a guardian in the suit had no authority to enter into any compromise or agreement purporting to bind the minor

precedents.citation: Parmeshwari Singh v. Banjit Singh 2 A.I.R. 1939 Pat. 33

anchor.surface_text: This principle has been applied also to cases where the provisions of 0. 32, r. 6 would apply and so it has been held in numerous cases in India that the Karta of a Hindu joint family though guardian in the suit cannot give a valid discharge in respect of a claim or a decree for is money or other movable property. Parmeshwari Singh v. Banjit Singh 2 and Letchmana Chetty v. Subbiah Chetty 3

precedents.cited_proposition: the Karta of a Hindu joint family though guardian in the suit cannot give a valid discharge in respect of a claim or a decree for money or other movable property

precedents.citation: Letchmana Chetty v. Subbiah Chetty 3 1924 I.L.R. 47 Mad. 920

anchor.surface_text: Parmeshwari Singh v. Banjit Singh 2 and Letchmana Chetty v. Subbiah Chetty 3 In the present case however there is numberscope for the application of either the provisions of 0. 32, r. 6 or O.32, r. 7 of the Code of Civil Procedure. Neither is 1 1913 L.R. 40 I.A. 132,138 2 A.I.R. 1939 Pat. 33. 3 1924 I.L.R. 47 Mad. 920. this a case of a receipt of any money or movable properties number is there any question of entering into an agreement or companypromise on behalf of the minor.

precedents.cited_proposition: the Karta of a Hindu joint family though guardian in the suit cannot give a valid discharge in respect of a claim or a decree for money or other movable property

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion nosubstance in this argument. The mere fact that the two illustrations to s. 7 are in respect of debts is numberground for thinking that the provisions of s. 7 are limited to suits or decrees on monetary claims only. Nor can we see any reason to think that the word discharge can refer only to debts. Discharge means, to free from liability. The liability may be in respect of monetary claims, like the debts it may be in respect of possession of property it may be in respect of taking some order as regards property it may be in respect of many other matters.
The High Court was therefore right in its conclusion that the application for execution was barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Equally untenable is the second argument that the provisions of 0. 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure debar the manager of a Hindu joint family from giving discharge in respect of a liability to deliver properties. Under the Hindu Law the Karta of a Hindu joint family represents all the members of the family and has the power and duty to take action which binds the family in connection with all matters of management of the family property.
The High Court was therefore right in its conclusion that the application for execution was barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that Jawala Prasad, the managing member of the family could have given a discharge of the liability under the partition decree by accepting delivery of possession on behalf of his minor sons without their consent and so time ran against them also under s. 7 of the Limitation Act from the date of the decree.
The High Court was therefore right in its conclusion that the application for execution was barred by limitation.
